sentence: And in my opening comments just now, I again emphasized something I’ve said prev iously, which is that if  the pace of progress in achieving our goals were to quicken, if it we re to accelerate, it’s likely that the Committee would begin raising its target fo r the federal funds rate sooner th an is now anticipated and might raise—might then raise the federal funds rate at a faster pace.

sentence: What I can say is that it is important for market participants to understand what our likely response  or reaction function is to the data, and our job is to try to communicate as clearly as we can the way in which our policy stance will depend on the data, and I promise to try to do that.

sentence: It’s not completely—so I’m giving my own personal view, not a Committee assessment—that, you know, I see the flat—and given the underlying downward trend in labor force particip ation, we might interpret the flattening out of labor force par ticipation over the last year as  showing that that cyclical component has diminished somewhat.

sentence: I think ther e is something that remains, but eventually I would certainly agree with the authors, we  should expect over time to see labor force participation declining.
reason: This sentence suggests a dovish stance on US monetary policy. The mention of labor force participation declining implies a potential slowdown in economic growth, which could lead to a more accommodative monetary policy to stimulate the economy.

sentence: Well, you know, we stayed low for a very long time.
reason: This sentence suggests a dovish stance on US monetary policy as it implies that interest rates have been kept low for an extended period. sentence: We have been at zero for a very long time and below the leve ls that some common policy rules would now be suggesting, given the level of unemployment and infl ation.
reason: This sentence suggests a dovish stance on US monetary policy. sentence: We’ve also been doing unconventional policies, of course, buying assets.

sentence: And in a general sense, I think we have been lower for longe r than—if you complete that sentence—than many standard policy rules would suggest.
reason: This sentence suggests a dovish stance on US monetary policy. The speaker acknowledges that interest rates have been kept low for a longer period than what standard policy rules would recommend, indicating a willingness to prioritize economic stimulus over potential inflation concerns.

sentence: So, in a sens e, that is a policy that we have had.
reason: This sentence suggests that the mentioned policy has been in place previously. However, without further context, it is difficult to determine whether this policy is hawkish, dovish, neutral, or irrelevant to current US monetary policy.

sentence: And once we decide it’s appropriate to be gin to normalize policy and to rais e the level of our target for September 17, 2014   Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL  Page 17 of 22 short-term interest rates, it would still take some  time for rates to get back to levels—you can see in our projection that by the end of 2017, the partic ipants are, on average,  projecting that rates will reach the levels they consider normal in the longer run.

sentence: And, similarly, we could make a similar statement with respect to where th e funds rate would stand relative to the recommendations of rules.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it does not provide any indication of whether the stance is hawkish, dovish, or neutral. It merely discusses the possibility of making a statement regarding the funds rate's position relative to rule recommendations.

sentence: Well, I think it’s very natu ral that the Committee should have a range of opinion about a decision as crucial as what is  the right time to begin to normalize policy, and we do have a range of views in the Committee.
reason: This sentence suggests that there is a divergence of opinions within the Committee regarding the appropriate timing to start normalizing policy. It implies a neutral stance as it acknowledges the existence of different views, without explicitly leaning towards a hawkish or dovish bias.

sentence: Presidents Plosser and Fisher have been quite clear in all of their speeches recently in stating that they think the time has come to begin normalizing policy.
reason: This sentence suggests a hawkish stance on US monetary policy as Presidents Plosser and Fisher emphasize the need to start normalizing policy. Their clear statements indicate a willingness to tighten monetary measures, signaling a potential shift towards a less accommodative stance.

sentence: I think they, perhaps, have some concerns that if we don’t begin to do so soon that inflation will pick up above levels we—that they would consider desirable, or that they have some financial stability concerns.
reason: This sentence suggests a hawkish stance on US monetary policy. The speaker expresses concerns about potential inflationary pressures and financial stability risks if action is not taken soon.

sentence: So there’s been  a little bit of dow ngrading, I think, ev en this time in the longer-run normal growth rates that Committ ee participants have written down.
reason: This sentence suggests a slightly dovish tone as it mentions a downgrade in longer-run normal growth rates. This implies that Committee participants may have a more cautious outlook on the economy, which could influence US monetary policy decisions.

sentence: You are certainly right in saying that over a number of y ears now, there’s been a pa ttern of forecast errors in which either we’ve been on track with resp ect to unemployment or unemployment has come down in some cases faster than we anticipated, and yet growth has pretty persistently been surprising the Committee to the downside.
reason: This sentence suggests that the Committee has consistently underestimated economic growth while accurately predicting or experiencing lower unemployment rates. sentence: And th at is a statement about  productivity growth, which has been pretty disappointing.

sentence: It is one of a number of risks to the global economy, and we cer tainly hope that they will be successful in seeing the pace of growth and inflation pick up, and I think that will be good for the global economy and the United States.

sentence: So we are c onstantly discussing forward guidance and thinking about whether it’s appropriate and how to revise it.

sentence: And we did do a major overhaul of our forward guidance in March.
reason: This sentence implies that there was a significant change in the forward guidance of US monetary policy in March. sentence: I think the Committee part icipants who have spoken out on this topic recently want to make sure that we have the fl exibility—that the Committee has the flexibility to respond to unfolding developments.
reason: This sentence suggests a dovish stance on US monetary policy. The Committee participants emphasize the importance of maintaining flexibility to respond to unfolding developments, indicating a cautious approach towards potential changes in the policy.

sentence: They want to ma ke sure that if progre ss really does turn out to be faster than we have—we would expect, th at the Committee will be in a position to start sooner tightening monetary policy.
reason: This sentence suggests a hawkish stance on US monetary policy. It indicates that the Committee wants to be prepared to start tightening monetary policy sooner if progress exceeds expectations.

sentence: They do not wa nt to be locked into something that the markets see as a calendar-based and firm commitment.
reason: This sentence suggests a dovish stance on US monetary policy. The FOMC members express their reluctance to be bound by a calendar-based and firm commitment, indicating a preference for flexibility and adaptability in response to market conditions.

sentence: And so they want to emphasize data dependence of our policy and make sure that we have appropriate flexibil ity.

sentence: And I’ve said repeat edly, and I want to say again, that if events surprise us, and we’re moving more quickly to ward our objectives, and the Committee sees a need to move sooner or later depending on what th e data is, that we do f eel—I do feel we have the flexibility to move.
reason: This sentence suggests a neutral stance on US monetary policy. It indicates that the Committee is open to adjusting the timing of their actions based on data and unexpected events, showing flexibility in their approach.

sentence: And it is important fo r markets to understand that there is uncertainty, and this statement is not some sort of firm promise about a particular amount of time.

sentence: So on the first question of “some time” before rates return to normal levels, as I mentioned, you can see in the SEP that by the end of 2017, many participants are anticipating that rates will return to what they think ar e normal longer-ru n levels, but the economy, in their view, will have probably gotten back to normal levels of unemployment and near-normal levels of inflation sometime in 2016.

sentence: So that looks like a year or more in which rates would be below normal longer-run levels.

sentence: You know, this is somethi ng the Committee is going to have to discuss when the time comes to normalize polic y.

sentence: Looking back on the period, the run-up to the financial crisis, I don’t think, by any means, “m easured pace” and the very predictable pace of 25 basis points per meeting explains why we had a financial crisis, but it  may have diminished volatility and been a small contributing factor, and the Committee will have to think about how to do this.

sentence: I think many people in the aftermath of that episode think that somewhat less of a mechanical pace would perhaps be better, but this is a matter that we will, in due time, have to discuss.
